user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_add_response_entry_no_alloc_:
```c
bool
MHD_add_response_entry_no_alloc_ (struct MHD_Response *response,
                                  enum MHD_ValueKind kind,
                                  char *header,
                                  size_t header_len,
                                  char *content,
                                  size_t content_len)
{
  struct MHD_HTTP_Res_Header *hdr;

  mhd_assert (0 != header_len);
  mhd_assert (0 != content_len);
  if (NULL == (hdr = MHD_calloc_ (1, sizeof (struct MHD_HTTP_Res_Header))))
    return false;

  hdr->header = header;
  hdr->header_size = header_len;
  hdr->value = content;
  hdr->value_size = content_len;
  hdr->kind = kind;
  _MHD_insert_header_last (response, hdr);

  return true; /* Success exit point */
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function MHD_add_response_entry_no_alloc_:
#define MHD_calloc_(n, s) calloc((n),(s))
...
#define _MHD_insert_header_last(presponse, phdr) do{mhd_assert(NULL==phdr->next);mhd_assert(NULL==phdr->prev);if(NULL==presponse->last_header){mhd_assert(NULL==presponse->first_header);presponse->last_header=phdr;presponse->first_header=phdr;}else{mhd_assert(NULL!=presponse->first_header);presponse->last_header->next=phdr;phdr->prev=presponse->last_header;presponse->last_header=phdr;}\
}while(0)
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
bool
MHD_add_response_entry_no_alloc_ (struct MHD_Response *response,
                                  enum MHD_ValueKind kind,
                                  char *header,
                                  size_t header_len,
                                  char *content,
                                  size_t content_len)
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation in this function: MHD_add_response_entry_no_alloc_ performs no calls to any <string.h> functions (it only stores the provided header/content pointers and their lengths and inserts the header into a list). Therefore this function itself cannot produce out‑of‑bounds accesses via the standard string functions and does not violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17. (Note: a violation could occur elsewhere if the stored hdr->header or hdr->value is later used with strcpy/strncpy/strlen/etc. without respecting hdr->header_size or hdr->value_size — e.g. calling strcpy(hdr->header, src) when strlen(src)+1 > hdr->header_size would violate Rule 21.17.)
